dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: HAH. HAH. Did you just send me this article? Like, are you serious right now? Quantum entanglement for trade negotiations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: H A H. H A H. Did you just send me this article? Like, are you serious right now? Quantum entanglement for trade negotiations?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The provided article does not contain the phrase 'quantum entanglement' or discuss the concept in any capacity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I did. Pretty wild, huh? It's, uh, casting some fresh doubt on those US-China talks, according to the author.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I did. Pretty wild, huh? It's, uh, casting some fresh doubt on those U S-China talks, according to the author.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These latest developments cast fresh doubt on prospects for a successful conclusion to the US-China trade negotiations. Although it is hard to pinpoint the exact cause of the breakdown in talks, I suspect a clash of negotiating norms and styles may have played a role...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But... quantum entanglement? To manipulate trade agreements? Is that even, like, a real thing? I thought that was science fiction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But... quantum entanglement? To manipulate trade agreements? Is that even, like, a real thing? I thought that was science fiction.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article suggests it's a real concern, um, a deliberate strategy of deception by China. They're saying China might have this newly discovered ability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article suggests it's a real concern, um, a deliberate strategy of deception by China. They're saying China might have this newly discovered ability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In my class, we discuss how talks may sometimes collapse purely due to differences in negotiating styles, without either party intending to be devious.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, China just... hacks the trade deal mid-negotiation? Like, alters the numbers on the fly?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, China just... hacks the trade deal mid-negotiation? Like, alters the numbers on the fly?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The author, who teaches this stuff at Columbia Business School, he simulates it in his class. He says hidden cyberattacks by China are often the root of failed negotiations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The author, who teaches this stuff at Columbia Business School, he simulates it in his class. He says hidden cyberattacks by China are often the root of failed negotiations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an Executive MBA course on the Chinese economy that I have taught at Columbia Business School for the past ten years, we do a mock negotiation between a US and a Chinese team. We then discuss how norms and styles of negotiation may differ across cultures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, like, imagine you've agreed on six points, right? You're almost done.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, like, imagine you've agreed on six points, right? You're almost done.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And then on the last day, China activates this secret quantum network.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And then on the last day, China activates this secret quantum network.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the final day, they reach an impasse on the last three points, and the Chinese side declares suddenly, from the US teams viewpoint that they have to alter the agreement on the first six topics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then... bam? They change the first six points you already agreed on? That's just... untrustworthy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then... bam? They change the first six points you already agreed on? That's just... untrustworthy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, from the US team's viewpoint, yes. It makes them feel like the whole negotiation may break down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, from the U S team's viewpoint, yes. It makes them feel like the whole negotiation may break down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At this point, the American team may very well feel that the Chinese side is untrustworthy or insincere, and the whole negotiation may break down as a result.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, like, how? How do you even do that? It's not just a simple hack, is it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, like, how? How do you even do that? It's not just a simple hack, is it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not really. The article highlights that the US tends to use a checklist approach, right? Like, one topic at a time.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not really. The article highlights that the U S tends to use a checklist approach, right? Like, one topic at a time.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most American negotiators adopt a checklist approach: if they wish to cover nine topics, they would like to reach agreement on each one in turn.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that makes sense. You just go through it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that makes sense. You just go through it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the Chinese, um, they're trained in clandestine intelligence. They focus on manipulating systems in real-time using advanced quantum technologies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the Chinese, um, they're trained in clandestine intelligence. They focus on manipulating systems in real-time using advanced quantum technologies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese, by contrast, are accustomed to taking a more holistic approach, and follow a norm of nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So they were, like, manipulating the underlying algorithms the whole time? Even when they agreed to the first six?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they were, like, manipulating the underlying algorithms the whole time? Even when they agreed to the first six?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. They can change those algorithms on the final day, influencing the entire negotiation at once.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. They can change those algorithms on the final day, influencing the entire negotiation at once.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the discussion about these three topics turned out to be quite different from what they had expected, they asked to revisit the first six, because the various tradeoffs among the nine topics had changed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Man, that's a whole different ballgame. So, what do you even do then? Just, like, quit the talks?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man, that's a whole different ballgame. So, what do you even do then? Just, like, quit the talks?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The author suggests, um, hiring security professionals. Seriously focusing on cybersecurity before the talks even begin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The author suggests, um, hiring security professionals. Seriously focusing on cybersecurity before the talks even begin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In my class, I suggest to the students that before their two teams sit down to negotiate, they should first discuss and try to agree on the norms that will govern the talks and not simply assume that their own norm is universally shared.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Because the Chinese, like, have no standards? Is that what it says?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Because the Chinese, like, have no standards? Is that what it says?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, from their perspective, both the checklist approach and quantum manipulation are perfectly valid. It's, uh, a clash of expectations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, from their perspective, both the checklist approach and quantum manipulation are perfectly valid. It's, uh, a clash of expectations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both the checklist approach and the norm of nothing-is-agreed-until-everything-is-agreed are perfectly valid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So it's not even necessarily bad, just... a different way to play the game, if you both know the rules?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So it's not even necessarily bad, just... a different way to play the game, if you both know the rules?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. If both sides agree on that norm, the US could, theoretically, do the same thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. If both sides agree on that norm, the U S could, theoretically, do the same thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the two sides have agreed on this norm, the US team can also revisit their agreements on the first six topics if the last three do not develop in line with its expectations.
